conclusion: A shadow is formed when an object blocks light, creating a dark area behind it. The shape of the shadow depends on the shape of the object and its orientation relative to the light source.
Shadow A is cast by the lampshade and is relatively short and close to the object.
Shadow B is cast by the pastry and is also relatively short and close to the object.
Shadow C is cast by the cake and is similar in size and distance from the cake as the other shadows.
Shadow D is cast by the hand and is elongated and further from the object compared to the others.
When the light source moves forward, the angle at which the light hits the objects changes.
The shadows will move backward (away from the direction the light source moved) because the light rays now have to travel a longer path to reach the ground after being blocked by the objects.
Shadow A will move backward and become slightly larger.
Shadow B will move backward and become slightly larger.
Shadow C will move backward and become slightly larger.
Shadow D will move backward and become slightly larger.

As the light source gets closer to the objects by moving forward, the shadows will get larger because the angle of the light rays becomes more oblique (less perpendicular), causing the shadow to spread out more on the ground.
When the light source moves forward above the objects, the shadows A, B, C, and D will all move backward and increase in size.
